page.title: 04CONGLETON EDGE CONTINUED
page.content: One of the dominant {geological} {features}of Congleton is the {scarp} {slope}of Congleton Edge.It is composed of Chatsworth grit,belonging to the {Namurian series}of the carboniferous } era.The ridge is rich with vegetation: chiefly{heather and deciduous trees. Such vegetation is concentrated in a small area of the westside of the ridge acting as a natural barrier between Congleton and Biddulph.The farmland is put to a variety of uses: dairy cattle occupy some fields;cereal crops are cultivated in others;and the rest are given to rough pasture.In some parts of the ridge is evidence of former quarrying for sandstone.The path is dotted with boulders which sometimes give way to soft springy peat and turf,all part of the carboniferous series.
